<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TranslatePath:
```c
int32 OS_TranslatePath(const char *VirtualPath, char *LocalPath)
{
    OS_object_token_t             token;
    int32                         return_code;
    const char *                  name_ptr;
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *filesys;
    size_t                        SysMountPointLen;
    size_t                        VirtPathLen;
    size_t                        VirtPathBegin;

    /*
    ** Check to see if the path pointers are NULL
    */
    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(VirtualPath);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(LocalPath);

    /*
    ** Check length
    */
    VirtPathLen = OS_strnlen(VirtualPath, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN);
    if (VirtPathLen >= OS_MAX_PATH_LEN)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG;
    }

    /* checks to see if there is a '/' somewhere in the path */
    name_ptr = strrchr(VirtualPath, '/');
    if (name_ptr == NULL)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }

    /* strrchr returns a pointer to the last '/' char, so we advance one char */
    name_ptr = name_ptr + 1;
    if (memchr(name_ptr, 0, OS_MAX_FILE_NAME) == NULL)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG;
    }

    SysMountPointLen = 0;
    VirtPathBegin    = VirtPathLen;

    /*
    ** All valid Virtual paths must start with a '/' character
    */
    if (VirtualPath[0] != '/')
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }

    /* Get a reference lock, as a filesystem check could take some time. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint,
                                         (void *)VirtualPath, &token);

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }
    else
    {
        filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, token);

        if ((filesys->flags & OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_SYSTEM) != 0)
        {
            SysMountPointLen = OS_strnlen(filesys->system_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->system_mountpt));
            VirtPathBegin    = OS_strnlen(filesys->virtual_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt));
            if (SysMountPointLen < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN)
            {
                memcpy(LocalPath, filesys->system_mountpt, SysMountPointLen);
            }
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if (VirtPathLen < VirtPathBegin)
        {
            return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
        }
        else
        {
            VirtPathLen -= VirtPathBegin;
            if ((SysMountPointLen + VirtPathLen) < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN)
            {
                memcpy(&LocalPath[SysMountPointLen], &VirtualPath[VirtPathBegin], VirtPathLen);
                LocalPath[SysMountPointLen + VirtPathLen] = 0;
            }
            else
            {
                return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG;
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>

{
    const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen);

        maxlen = end - s;

                             OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(MatchFunc, arg, token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "lock_mode" parameter.

        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}

explanation:
I examined all uses of the function parameters VirtualPath and LocalPath in OS_TranslatePath. There are no assignments to either parameter (no statements like VirtualPath = ... or LocalPath = ...), no increments/decrements of those pointer variables, and none of the addresses of the parameter variables are taken and passed to other functions (only the pointer values are passed). Specific points considered:

- VirtualPath is only read (passed to strnlen, strrchr, memchr, indexed as VirtualPath[0], used in memcpy as source and passed as the void* arg value to OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch). Reading from the pointed-to object and copying bytes from it is allowed by the rule; the pointer variable itself is not modified.
- LocalPath is only used as a destination buffer (memcpy(LocalPath, ...), memcpy(&LocalPath[...], ...), and writing the terminating NUL). Modifying the object pointed to is explicitly permitted by the rule; LocalPath itself is not reassigned.
- name_ptr is a local pointer variable (not a parameter); its modification does not relate to Rule 17.8.
- Passing (void *)VirtualPath to OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch casts away constness but passes the pointer value by value; the called function cannot modify the caller’s parameter variable itself unless its address were passed, which is not done here.
- Macros and helper functions used (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_strnlen, OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch, OS_ObjectIdRelease, memcpy, memchr, strrchr) do not assign to the parameter variables in this function.

Therefore there are no code fragments in OS_TranslatePath that modify a function parameter pointer itself and no fragments needing investigation for potential violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
